dc:title: The influence of cyclones on the dry evergreen forest of Sri Lanka.
dc:creator: Dittus W.
dc:description: Damage included defoliation, breakage of twigs, branches and trunks, tree falls and post-cyclone tree mortality. Extrapolations from meteorological data indicate that 33-44% of the range of dry evergreen forest may be subject to cyclone damage per century. The species composition of dry evergreen forest on a local and wider geographical scale typically is fairly uniform in the subcanopy layer, but variable in the upper layers. Recurrent cyclone damage may be an important factor contributing to succession in dry evergreen forest and to the variation in species composition of the upper layers. -from Author

dc:title: Leaf litter disappearance rates in Puerto Rican montane rain forest.
dc:creator: La Caro F.
dc:description: Dacryodes excelsa, Sloanea berteriana and Drypetes glauca were chosen to represent primary climax species, while Cecropia peltata, Inga vera and Ixora ferrea were selected to represent secondary successional species. The secondary canopy species exhibited slower decay rates. The same pattern emerged between the secondary and primary understory species. The interacting effects of the leaf structural characteristics such as percentage lignin and percentage fiber correlated most strongly with observed decay rates. Nutrients were important in establishing organic matter resource quality but did not appear to influence decay rates; instead, nutrient dynamics reflected intervals of element immobilization, mineralization and importation. Secondary species exhibiting specific combinations of structural properties may act to conserve nutrient by their slower rates of leaf litter disappearance.-from Authors

dc:title: Seasonality and diversity of mayfly adults ( Ephemeroptera) in a 'nonseasonal' tropical environment.
dc:creator: Wolda H.
dc:description: Fluctuations in abundance of adult Ephemeroptera were analyzed from a year of daily light-trap collections at Miramar, a relatively nonseasonal locality of NW Panama. Most taxa occurred year-round; some showed within-year fluctuations in abundance that may be seasonal. Species of Leptohyphes showed a pronounced lunar periodicity. -from Authors

dc:title: (Some aspects of a community of snakes of the north of Venezuela).
dc:creator: Silva L. J.L.
dc:description: The most abundant species were: Liophis reginae (23.7%), Mastigodryas boddaerti (10.1%), Stenorrhina degenhardtii (8.5%), Bothrops colombiensis (7.7%), Atractus lancinii (6.5%), and Dendrophidion percarinatus (5.8%). Family Colubridae and terrestrial snakes occupied the first place in taxonomic and life form order of importance respectively. Diurnal and nocturnal activity of 14 species, and daily activity rhythms were examined. -from English summary

dc:title: Litter fall of Avicennia germinans L. in a one-year cycle in a mudflat at the laguna de Mecoacan, Tabasco, Mexico.
dc:creator: Lopez-Portillo J.
dc:description: Mean total annual litter fall was 614.4 g.m-1.yr-1. Seasonal fluctuations of mean water level, insolation, temperature and evaporation were highly intercorrelated and were summarized in a principal component axis that explains 82% of their variability. Each litter component (leaves, flowers and reproductive parts, branches and woody parts, and propagules) shows a distinctive sequence, and significant correlations were obtained when comparing the principal component axis against leaf and propagule fall. Phenologic variation in litter fall as an adaptive response to environmental changes is discussed.-from Authors

dc:title: Breeding systems in the flora of a tropical deciduous forest in Mexico.
dc:creator: Bullock S.
dc:description: Floral sexuality was characterized for most of the flora (708 species) of a forest reserve at Chamela, Jalisco, and compatability was determined for a sample of hermaphroditic species. Nine types of floral sexuality were found: frequency was related to life form and systematics. Monostylous hermaphroditism was typical of epiphytes (96%) and herbs (82%) but less so among vines (68%), shrubs (62%), and trees (54%). Dioecy increased across these groups (4%, 1%, 10%, 14%, and 24%, respectively). Monoecy was concentrated in Euphorbiaceae and Cucurbitaceae; Boraginaceae and Rubiaceae predominated among the few distylous species. Compatability tests showed reduced fruiting from self- compared to cross-pollination in 94% of 33 species from 14 families, and 76% were considered self-incompatible.-from Author

dc:title: How fast and why do germinating guanacaste seeds ( Enterolobium cyclocarpum) die inside cows and horses?
dc:creator: Janzen D.
dc:description: One day of exposure to either rumen or caecal in vitro fermentation killed 90% of scarified seeds, and none survived >2 days. No unscarified seeds germinated. Scarification appears to be a critical process affecting survivorship of seeds in the guts of large, mammalian herbivores. Because functional differences in the foregut between ruminants and nonruminants impose different chewing patterns and passage rates on these groups, these factors are probably responsible for the lower proportion of scarified seeds in the feces of ruminants. In the large mammalian herbivores, nonruminants function as seed predators while ruminants are better disposal agents for guanacaste seeds.-from Authors

dc:title: Relationships between soil and vegetation in a tropical rain forest in French Guiana.
dc:creator: Lescure J.P.
dc:description: Structural data of the vegetation are correlated to soils characteristics as well as the frequencies and densities of 32 taxa. -from Authors

dc:title: Perching heights and nocturnal communal roosts of some tiger beetles ( Coleoptera: Cicindelidae) in southeastern Peru.
dc:creator: Pearson D.
dc:description: When disturbed, diurnally active species of tiger beetles flew from the forest floor, where they foraged, to temporary perches in the vegetation. Height of perch was correlated with size of species. At night, these species roosted for 10-12 hr at the same height as their temporary daytime perches. Some species congregated nocturnally on communal roosts of 2-9 individuals during the early rainy season. Species from sandy edges of rivers roosted on grass blades at night. -from Authors

dc:title: The palm community in a forest of central Amazonia, Brazil.
dc:creator: Kahn F.
dc:description: The palm community showed 3 zones according to the hydromorphic condition of the soil: well-drained soils of the upland forest, poorly-drained soils of a transition zone, and water-logged soils of the seasonal swamp forest. The community is remarkable in its size (with 2122 palms/ha, and the highest density on water-logged soils); its great diversity (32 species/1.2 ha), which also depends on the hydromorphic condition of the soil; and its variety of biological forms with characteristic acaulescent palms in the understory, monocaulous and multiple-stemmed palms in the upper understory, and arborescent palms only reaching the canopy in the seasonal swamp forest. -from Authors

dc:title: Soil response to forest clearing in the United States and the tropics: geological and biological factors.
dc:creator: Allen J.
dc:description: Organic C, total N, exchangeable Ca, Mg, and K, cation exchange capacity, available P, bulk density, and pH were considered. After forest clearing, only bulk density and available P tended to return to preclearing levels. Losses of organic C, total N, and cation exchange capacity were 50% larger in soils developed on highly weathered parent materials in the tropics than in the same soils in the USA or in soils developed on young parent materials. Differences in soil response to clearing were related to local effects of temperature, rainfall, vegetation type, and soil acidity on organic matter decomposition.-from Author

dc:title: Germination response in a large-seeded neotropical tree species, Gustavia superba ( Lecythidaceae).
dc:creator: Sork V.
dc:description: Although seedling densities of G. superba in a tropical moist forest in Panama varied inversely with age of forest, there was no evidence that germination success contributes to this pattern. This species germinates readily under most conditions: the overall mean was 85.4% and only 6 of 72 plots had <70% germination. Germination percent was reduced and mean number of days until germination was increased in the largest light gap. Burial of seeds and microsite conditions had minor effects on germination. Seedling mortality occurring soon after germination was not large (5.7%). -from Author

dc:title: Spatial variation in the structure and litterfall of a Sumatran rain forest.
dc:creator: Van Schaik C.
dc:description: The forest consisted of a series of topographical units of increasing age and decreasing pH and fertility. With increasing soil age, production of leaf litter and fruit decreased whereas the proportion of mature-phase forest increased and gap cover decreased. There is variation in the growth strategies of trees depending on soil fertility; this results in higher tree longevity on poor soils, and hence in forest with fewer gaps and with more large trees, than on rich soils. -from Authors

dc:title: Pollen carrying by the nectar-feeding bat Glossophaga soricina in a suburban environment.
dc:creator: Lemke T.O.
dc:description: Five species of plants were visited by Glossophaga soricina in a suburban area in Colombia. Agave desmettiana was the only species to flower year-round and the only one not observed to be visited by other pollen vectors.-from Author

dc:title: Brackish water and soil components of mangrove forests on Iriomote Island, Japan.
dc:creator: Kuraishi S.
dc:description: Fringe and riverine forests of mangroves occur along the Shiira River of Iriomote Island. Sonneratia alba is distributed around the river mouth as a fringe forest. A mixed forest of Rhizophora stylosa and Bruguiera gymnorrhiza, a pure forest of Bruguiera, and a mixed forst of Bruguiera and nonmangrove plants are seen between 0-0.4, 0.4-1.5, and 1.5-2.0 km from the river mouth, respectively. The soils of Bruguiera-dominated forests 1) contained less sand and more clay for a lower bulk density than fringe forest soils; 2) had more humus, lower phosphate absorption, and a higher cation exchange capacity than those of the fringe forests; and 3) were always in a highly reduced state.-from Authors

dc:title: Breeding productivity and the non-breeding element in some montane forest birds in Malawi, south-central Africa.
dc:creator: Dowsett-Lemaire F.
dc:description: Secondary productivity (0.4-1.9 young/breeding pair) was low as a result of small clutches, short breeding seasons and, in some species, low nesting success. Most of the 7 studied species could replace failed clutches, but 2nd broods were suspected in only moustached green tinkerbird Pagoniulus leucomystax. In most species the first breeding attempt was delayed until age 2 yr. Unfavorable environmental conditions in some seasons were associated with decreased secondary productivity, and some pairs even refrained from attempting to breed. -from Author

dc:title: The influence of leaf- monkeys on their feeding trees in a cyclone-disturbed environment.
dc:creator: Dittus W.
dc:description: A cyclone in November 1978 caused extensive damage to a site of natural dry evergreen forest in Sri Lanka. The cyclone destroyed >50% of the woody vegetation that had produced most of the food for 2 species of leaf-eating monkeys (langurs). This caused an imbalance between the langur populations and their natural food supply and resulted in overbrowsing on feeding trees not destroyed by the cyclone. Preferentially browsed tree species that were relatively rare and/or small in size died at significantly greater rates due to overbrowsing than those which were buffered against overbrowsing by virtue of being large in tree size and/or relatively abundant.-from Author

dc:title: Foraging behavior of the African insectivorous bat, Scotophilus leucogaster.
dc:creator: Barclay R.
dc:description: Scotophilus leucogaster was studied in Zimbabwe, during January and February (normally the wet season). Diet and foraging behavior appear to be variable. Individuals foraged primarily over floodplains for an average of <1 hr at dusk and spent the rest of the night in small tree-cavity roosts. Adults averaged shorter feeding periods and remained closer to the roost area than did subadults. Hemipterans and coleopterans were the primary prey items although a number of other insect orders were eaten. Diet varied between adults and subadults and from night to night. It was also more varied than that previously reported for this species during the wet season, a fact potentially due to previous abnormally dry conditions. -from Author

dc:title: Site fidelity and survival rates of some montane forest birds in Malawi, south-central Africa.
dc:creator: Dowsett R.
dc:description: From 1972-1982, 2030 forest birds of 33 species were banded in a study area on the Nyika Plateau, Malawi/Zambia. Movements and survival of these birds, particularly starred robin Pogonocichla stellata, were monitored during three breeding seasons, 1979-1982. Overall, average movement recorded was 165 m. Five species of passerines moved from the largest forest into the smallest patches (c2.5 km), but most territorial adults were strictly sedentary, especially during the breeding season. Most species maintained long-term pair bonds, but all female Pogonocichla left the study area in the nonbreeding season and returned regularly to the same territory each year. -from Author

dc:title: Tree mortality in mangrove forests.
dc:creator: Jimenez J.A.
dc:description: Twenty-eight worldwide reports of massive mangrove tree mortalities are reviewed. Normal tree mortality, described using structural data from 114 mangrove stands, is density dependent, follows orderly time dependent patterns dictated by stand maturation and usually occurs in the smaller diameter size classes. Disease and other biotic factors are not primary causes of massive mangrove mortalities. Instead, these factors appear to attack forests weakened by changes in the physical environment. Mangrove enviornments are dynamic and cyclical and mangrove associations adapt to such environments by both growing and dying fast. Mangrove species' characteristics such as the capacity to produce large quantities of propagules that take advantage of dispersal agents, sharp species zonations, and even-aged populations contribute to the rapid growth-mortality cycles in mangroves. Humans may tilt the balance towards higher mortality rates by introducing chronic stressors that inhibit regeneration mechanisms.-from Authors

dc:title: Microbiology of the larval provisions of the stingless bee, Trigona hypogea, an obligate necrophage.
dc:creator: Gilliam M.
dc:description: Five species of the genus Bacillus were the only microbes found in the larval provisions of Trigona hypogea, a bee for which dead animal tissue has replaced pollen as the sole protein source. They may have a fundamental role in the metabolic conversion, fermentation, and preservation of the food of perennial colonial insects that rely on stored food in tropical environments. -from Author

dc:title: Adjusting foraging effort to resources in adjacent colonies of the leaf-cutter ant, Atta colombica.
dc:creator: Shepherd J.D.
dc:description: A colony located in older, secondary forest used 130 different resource species and had a dietary diversity equal to 30.7 equally-used species. This colony showed a cyclical annual pattern of gradually changing diet. An adjacent colony in younger, secondary forest used 103 plant species and had a dietary diversity of only 11.8 equally-utilized species. Foraging by this colony was governed by the availability of a small number of high quality resource species. Tree species eliciting a strong recruitment of foragers from the colony were denser in the younger forest suggesting that the colony in the younger forest was specializing in a richer resource environment. A weak correlation between maximum harvest rates and the synchrony of leaf production may indicate that the phenology of leaf production serves as a predator-avoidance mechanism. -from Author

dc:title: Interactions among leaf-top herbivores of Heliconia imbricata ( Zingiberales: Heliconiaceae).
dc:creator: McCoy E.
dc:description: One study consisted of monitoring the colonization of experimental patches of habitat (cacao leaves) to see if colonists preferred uninhabited patches. A 2nd study involved placing various numbers of Cephaloleia consanguinea larvae under experimental patches, and monitoring their departure. Evidence for interference between colonist and resident individuals of some morphotypes and among C. consanguinea larvae at high densities was obtained. Neither experiment indicated that interference contributes significantly to guild structure among these Costa Rican herbivores. -from Author

dc:title: Seed weight as a function of life form, elevation and life zone in neotropical forests.
dc:creator: Rockwood L.
dc:description: Tropical species show significant differences in seed weight means among trees, shrubs and herbs (largest to smallest). Tropical epiphytes, however, show a biomodal pattern; though seeds from some plant families (eg Orchidaceae) are tiny, many epiphyte seeds (primarily from Melastomataceae, Gesneriaceae and Bromeliaceae) were equivalent to, or larger than, those of shrubs. Seeds from tropical herbaceous vines were comparable in weight to those of herbs, while seeds of woody lianas (all from Bignoniaceae) were comparable to trees in weight. Seed weights analyzed by elevation and life zone showed no conclusive patterns.-from Author

dc:title: Some floral nectar-sugar compositions from Durango and Sinaloa, Mexico.
dc:creator: Freeman C.
dc:description: Nectar-sugar compositions of 34 species and 18 families of tropical and subtropical plants from W-central Mexico were determined. Most are hummingbird-pollinated, but hawkmoth, bee, perching bird and taxa of unknown or uncertain pollinators are also represented.-from Authors

dc:title: Herbivory and defense in pioneer, gap and understory trees of tropical rain forests in French Guiana.
dc:creator: Newbery D.
dc:description: Mature leaves of the shaded forest understory were more heavily (>3-fold) grazed than those on pioneer trees and small trees which grow up from the saplings in lighted gaps; young leaves did not differ significantly in levels of defoliation between vegetation types. Defoliation levels averaged 5.5% on mature leaves. Herbivory on mature leaves was significantly negatively correlated with total leaf phenols. These chemicals may be deterring herbivory on pioneer and gap leaves, but a more likely primary cause is that total phenols are higher in plants in direct light than in those in shade conditions.-from Authors

dc:title: A migration of Urania fulgens (Uraniidae) in Costa Rica.
dc:creator: Odendaal F.J.
dc:description: A migration of the diurnal moth Urania fulgens showed unusual timing, taking place in the dry season and consisting of females with large batches of mature eggs. The migrant/non-migrant ratio may differ among migrations, and migrations may take place for different reasons, some of which may relate to seasonally modulated availability of larval food plants. -from Authors

dc:title: Seasonal predation by merlins on sooty mustached bats in western Puerto Rico.
dc:creator: Rodriguez-Duran A.
dc:description: Predation by Falco columbarius on the insectivorous bat Pteronotus fuliginosus was studied in winter at a cave. Falcons were present from October-April, reaching maximum densities in January and February. Predation efficiency of falcons was greater at the more exposed of 2 flyways used by bats. The falcon using the most easily observed perch captured an average of 5.1 bats/day. In the first season falcons took 1.5% of the bat standing crop. By the end of the 2nd year the exposed flyway was no longer used by bats. -from Authors

dc:title: Mice ( Peromyscus maniculatus, P. spicilegus and Microtus mexicanus) as predators of overwintering monarch butterflies ( Danaus plexippus) in Mexico.
dc:creator: Brower L.P.
dc:description: Mice do not select or reject butterflies on the basis of cardenolide content. Rather than being adversely affected by feeding on monarchs, female mice were found to be larger, heavier, and reproductively more active in the butterfly colonies than outside them. The mutual impact between the Peromyscus population and the butterflies may be substantial. -from Authors

dc:title: On the accuracy of estimating aboveground tree biomass in an evergreen forest near Manaus, Brazil. A simulation study.
dc:creator: Hase H.
dc:description: Confidence intervals for the estimates of leaf biomass and twig/wood biomass in a tropical rain forest were calculated using data from a complete inventory. The influence of sample size and calculation method (mean tree technique or regression technique) on the accuracy and precision of the biomass estimates is discerned. A stratified random sample of 10-15% of all trees, selected on the basis of D2H, will yield confidence intervals (P = 0.05) of 75-125% and 90-110% for the estimate of leaf biomass or twig/wood biomass per unit area, respectively. -Authors

dc:title: Bat pollination of an old world Heliconia.
dc:creator: Kress W.
dc:description: In the Solomon Islands Heliconia solomonensis with pendent, green, inconspicuous inflorescences is pollinated by the macroglossine bat Melonycteris woodfordi. The green and white, odorless flowers open in the evening and produce copious (>200 microliters/night), moderately concentrated, sucrose-dominant nectar. H. solomonensis is probably self-incompatible. Melonycteris is a solitary forager that visits inflorescences of Heliconia in a sequential fashion. Nectar is taken from open flowers by the bat in such a fashion that pollen is deposited on the underside of its neck and chin.-from Author

dc:title: The role of nectar and oil in the pollination of Drymonia serrulata ( Gesneriaceae) by Epicharis bees ( Anthophoridae) in Panama.
dc:creator: Steiner K.
dc:description: The main pollinators of Drymonia serrulata in Panama are Epicharis monozona and E. rustica. Visitors that remove nectar, but are ineffectivce pollinators include 7 Euglossa spp. and 3 species of matinal butterflies (Hesperiidae).-from Author

dc:title: Euryphagy in a tropical snake, Coniophanes fissidens.
dc:creator: Seib R.
dc:description: Coniophanes fissidens exhibits individual, ontogenetic, temporal and geographic variation in diet. -from Author

dc:title: A disturbing synergism between cattle ranch burning practices and selective tree harvesting in the eastern Amazon.
dc:creator: Uhl C.
dc:description: The combination of pasture burning to control weeds and selective timber harvesting is resulting in the spread of wildfires in Amazonian rain forests in Para, Brazil. -from Authors

dc:title: The influence of fruit size and structure on composition of frugivore assemblages in New Guinea.
dc:creator: Pratt T.K.
dc:description: Large (diam. >12 mm) structurally unprotected fruits were taken mostly by fruit-pigeons and bowerbirds; structurally-protected fruits were taken mostly by birds of paradise; and small, structurally-unprotected fruits were taken by nearly all species. Fruit-pigeons have short, thin bills; small feet; and fewer behaviors for reaching and handling fruits. Birds of paradise use complex food-handling techniques for removing fruits in capsules and other protective structures that are similar to techniques used to capture insects hidden in bark and dried foliage. Attracting specific feeding assemblages might be regarded as an adaptation of the plant for enhancing particular patterns of seed dispersal.-from Authors
